author: Paris Lee
content:
I’m not really qualified to speak from any technical standpoint of anything discussed here, especially among the giants and don’t want to look stupid …but as someone who DJ’d House, Techno, Drum and Bass etc back in the late 90’s as a teenager in LA on Vinyl (I’m 45 now), watched the transfer to CD’js…(no idol of mine has touched a vinyl in 20 years) and masters for modern EDM artists, I feel like I can speak with some authority about, I dunno, *something*…Back in those days, I guess Ill just say there were a lot of factors that influenced what sounded so good about that era, and what producers did then. The dynamics, combined with the *type of low frequency* content of those genres at that time, along with DJ’s who knew what the fuck they were doing, along with sound crews who worked the rave circuit and were continually hired and worked with the same DJ’s, all contributed so much to this magic rave Vinyl era.
There’s nothing that touched those deep kickass lows back then, But That was the style! 
So much has changed. Producers back then got their loudness from pushing analog desks into the red, Simple Mackie desks, stuff like that. But We moved to an all digital world. I remember when the first pioneer digital DJ mixers came out, I’d put a vinyl on and just be like…this is shit! where’s my headroom?!?! the frequency distribution of the music has also changed, DJ’s also got more concerned with jumping up and down and clapping rather than mixing and gain staging. Clubs started putting limiters on the systems 
Most of these kids doing EDM at high levels-really don’t even need ME’s at all! Their mix busses are so super complex. If they took that stuff off, I’d be totally lost. But they like a little analog processing in a lot of cases. Loudness, they *don’t need*
Clipping, limiting, whatever, it’s the modern thing- If i can help I can- and I tell them not to change a thing- just back off the limiter until the exact moment where the track loses the vibe. Then I go.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Below I am sharing something that I send to my mastering clients when they inquire about targeting LUFS levels for streaming services. I hope it is helpful to some readers. Discussion is welcome.


Regarding mastering to streaming LUFS loudness normalization targets, i.e. -14 LUFS - I do not recommend trying to do that. I know it's discussed all over the web, but in reality very few people actually do it. To test this, try turning loudness matching off in Spotify settings, then check out the tracks listed under "New Releases" and see if you can find material that's not mastered to modern loudness for it's genre. You will probably find little to none. Here's why people aren't doing it:

1 - In the real world, loudness normalization is not always engaged. For example, Spotify Web Player and Spotify apps integrated into third-party devices (such as speakers and TVs) do not have loudness normalization. YouTube is normalized but "YouTube Music" is not normalized. Apple Music's web player is not normalized. With normalization off, your -14 LUFS track will sound much softer than most other tracks.

2- Even with loudness normalization turned on, many people have reported that their -14 LUFS masters sound quieter than other tracks in playlists.

3 - Some streaming services have different loudness targets (Apple's is -16) and there's no guarantee they won't change their loudness targets again in the future. For example, Spotify lowered their loudness target by 3dB in 2017, then in 2021 they switched measurement from ReplayGain to LUFS. Also, in Spotify Premium app settings you find 3 different loudness settings; "Quiet, Normal, and Loud". Now AES is recommending that all music streaming services switch to -16 LUFS. It's a moving target. 

4 - Some people suggest making multiple masters at different levels. But digital aggregators (CD Baby, etc.) generally do not allow more than one version of each song, so you'd have to make separate paid submissions.

author: Rollmottle
content:
nah, fuck -1 or -2. theoretically the lower the ceiling, the less risk there is of intersample peaks happening upon conversion to MP3 or some other lossless format streamers use to stream audio to your device. even if there are ISP's, they usually light up a meter but are inaudible. i live at -0.5db for most everything. sometimes i'll go to -0.3db if it's something that is pop oriented (this is where i landed for @thejadenmejia's single for example). i think a lot of the panic about it is overblown. in the real world, clients like their shit loud.

as far as distro goes, i know some are starting to accept higher res files or even accepting multiple files. my deliverables have always been 96/24 and 44/16. I've recently started including 44/24's. i've always discouraged submitting anything other than 44/16 because who knows what some of these services are doing with SRC and dither, but i think with the advent of high res and lossless delivery, you are well-advised to submit the higher bit-rate files nowadays. all that said, with something like 44/24 you are probably pretty safe from getting your shit munched down-funnel.

author: eschirtz
content:
I hear you Ruairi, and ultimately you gotta make your own call on this. 

But I just wanna reassure you that our business is built around serving your type of workflow. Even if 99% of users don't give a shit about the perfect playback, we do. That's why we have that "lossless" switch. We'll never switch to AAC due to bandwidth issues.

The "constant upgrades" are often due to the ever changing landscape of browsers. Each client is often on a different browser, different device and different internet connection. It's our job to understand that landscape and push fixes to ensure we get perfect playback across all environments. 

That's part of the reason we built the iOS app, to be able to provide a more consistent playback experience when browsers themselves are the limiting factor, and so that clients can listen offline to take the network out of the equation. But I totally understand that you can't really ask a client to install another app on their iPhone. 

To my knowledge, Samply is still the only platform that lets clients stream full resolution lossless AND gapless track transitions in a browser. It's a really tough engineering challenge, but ultimately the backbone of our entire business. We're committed to continuing to solve this problem and evolve with the technology available.

author: Edsel Holden
content:
I will share words that are not mine (these words belong to @Nomograph Mastering )

Context is important here. This is an email that Nomogrpah wrote back to a client that said "Hey I love the master so much but I am a bit worried about how much it might get turned down ?" or something to that effect 

Response was 

"Glad you are feeling the master!

Re the level thing that is a complicated question. A few thoughts

Not everyone has loudness normalization turned on. It also doesn’t exist on Smart TVs, many streaming web interfaces etc

The different services all have different level norm targets (and even different settings within just Spotify) - and they change pretty regularly

In terms of absolute level when normalization is active what matters is arrangement (dense mixes sound quieter than sparse/spacious mixes), EQ (bright/mid range forward mixes sound louder than dark) and distortion levels (clipped/distorted mixes feel perceptually louder than clean). If I make a master a dB louder in mastering using just limiting for example, they just turn it down a dB more when it’s level normed.

So what does all of this mean? It means that every song has sweet spot where the EQ/tone, the arrangement and the overall clipping/limiting level works best and communicates the intent. That’s what we aim for.

You can use a site like loudnesspenalty.com to see what will happen but it will just drive you crazy and the only real way to meaningfully alter the result is to change the arrangement/mix or overall EQ a lot. On release day you can find 1000 records that are louder than yours if you want to.

If being the loudest is the intent - game everything listed above and you can “win”. If doing your unique thing and communicating a song and a performance is the goal then I think you are there!"

(posted with Nomographs permission)

author: Zach Hughes
content:
So this is straight from Spotify's website and obviously nobody really abides by it but I just want to know if theres a 'why':    *Target the loudness level of your master at -14dB integrated LUFS and keep it below -1dB TP (True Peak) max. This is best for lossy formats (Ogg/Vorbis and AAC) and makes sure no extra distortion’s introduced in the transcoding process.
If your master’s louder than -14dB integrated LUFS, make sure it stays below -2dB TP (True Peak) to avoid extra distortion. This is because louder tracks are more susceptible to extra distortion in the transcoding process.*

author: Zach Hughes
content:
A few thoughts on all this.. I agree with @Nomograph Mastering that the top of funnel for Spotify isn't bringing in enough money to overnight increase the amount music rights holders are paid. However, I am not convinced Spotify couldn't raise their subscription price in certain markets. Netflix has successfully raised their prices many times over the years. I've been paying the same price for Spotify for close to 10 years (maybe it increased a dollar at one point, but not sure).

I do believe Daniel Ek and Spotify have earned some ire from the music community. Ek is a billionaire and the average Spotify employee makes close to $110k / year. You would probably need around ~1.5 million monthly listeners and ~3.5 million streams / month to earn an equivalent amount (master recording side sans publishing and no other income stream). There are maybe a little over 6000 artists that have that large of a listenership in the entire world out of conservatively 5-7 million artists on the platform.

There are many things Spotify could do to improve economic outcomes for artists / musicians. Here are a few in no particular order:
1) Allow artists to link to their own website. Believe it or not we can't do this. Your own website is the one piece of online real estate that you actually control. On Spotify, IG, Tiktok, etc... you are playing in someone else's sandbox.
2) Allow artists more control over their profiles and the way they are laid out. One thing that infuriates me is how Spotify sorts albums by popularity rather than release date. I would like to change that. This would be beneficial to promoting newer releases. As well all external links off of Spotify are virtually hidden on the 'about' page at the bottom of your profile making it harder for fans to follow you where you want to be followed.

author: Conah Tucker
content:
Hey folks! Following on from this, had a bit of time today to do some more testing, I've done a pink noise test today. 1 track 3 different loudnesses 5db apart. Uploaded the different loudnesses separately too.

Finds: (please note this is off of web TikTok, app TikTok tests will come soon)
• -4.6db overall (planning on testing this more in depth, but occurred 4 times on the 4 different audios I uploaded)
• Int LUFS -7.4 down to -13.3 (for this specific case).
• 5db differences remain.
• Brickwall eq at 16khz (this was tested on many different videos).
• The different levels uploaded separately did not change their respective loudnesses compared to the full noise track. So dynamic sections of track shouldn't boost if uploaded as a separate sound to TikTok.
• No compression.
• General audio quality does drop.

Things that come to mind:
•  Common 3rd party video editing apps (such as capcut) and how they affect audio
• The level control TikTok users have and how that affects audio (in terms of peak/loudness and referring back to the -4.6db peak mentioned earlier)


I'll run some more tests when I get the time to.

This is honestly something to be aware of -- a lot of people never play digital master files at full volume off their phone -- they are comparing to something like Spotify or Apple which turns stuff down on normalization (and thus has peaks that are not near zero). author: Will Melones
content:
All I know is that a lot of folks think Spotify doesn’t have a limiter—it only turns *down* loud masters when normalization is enabled. In fact Spotify definitely DOES have a limiter, and if you deliver a master below -14 LUFS it will be turned UP, and anything over 0 will be smashed (only when normalization is enabled).

There is also a 3-level setting for volume when normalization is on, and the app tells you that sound quality *will* be affected at the loudest setting. Not sure how this works in real life.

author: Grover
content:
Surely there's something to learn from the history though yes? Cutting is what the profession of mastering used to be and digital is not wholly removed. We can certainly take learnings from our history while embracing modern methods. Cutting good vinyl is also respect for the folks who work on it and the artists who want their music conveyed appropriately across mediums. 

I have no problem making stuff massively loud with zero limiting and small amounts of soft clipping, and still retaining tons of transient peaks. I prefer this sound to heavy limiting at the master stage where the program material audibly hits the limiter and the soundstage and sense of headroom collapses. To me, the limiter is optional, but I do understand many use it before they acquire the skills to work without it. 

That said, I also was taught that in genres where its appropriate (Imagine Dragons, Hip hop, EDM, etc.) that those sounds should go in at the production or mixing stage. At the mastering stage I was taught to do no harm, and only to enhance what was present. In my work pushing more than a few dB into a limiter to affect the groove of a piece does not track with my understanding of doing as little to change the sound as possible. But of course, it all depends on the project. My clients who make very mainstream pop/youtube music don't particularly care if I radically editorialize as long as it sounds good and serves the tune. 

There's also something to be said for music which needs to be quiet. Not all music should be loudenated to within an inch of its life. Not all music needs quiet and intimacy. I think of we hold the pursuit of "the program material's individual requirements to be king" we cannot then also dismiss vinyl as unimportant or say that one MUST always do things a particular way.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
My 2 cents -- going forward those of us who think of mastering as "finishing" instead of "mastering" in the traditional sense might be very well equipped. I know Edsel you are similar -- but when I let go of the "this is what mastering IS" mindset, and leaned into the "this is the box in front of me I have to operate within", things got much better. Acceptance.

Is it mastering if I only work from a stereo file? A limited REF? Tearing apart an mp3 bounce with AI and remaking it? An Ableton session? I say yes to all if we are the ones getting the record across the line. 

That said, the traditional approach is IMO the best for many reasons, but in some sense just having a stereo file is an almost arbitrary restriction based on how projects are made and shared (though a good one). But as technology evolves and shifts, best to be on the cutting edge of knowing how to make a lot of situations work -- I bet the winners will be those who do

author: Zach Hughes
content: Day late and a dollar short but catching up on the Spotify convo from earlier. A few thoughts: I don't think or hope that Spotify will be gone in 5 years and if it is, that would be bad for most artists (at least in a vacuum). 66% of all the money I've made from DSPs in the past five years has been from Spotify and before this past year it was probably closer to 80% (had a track get lucky on Youtube Red and Amazon Music). I see similar distributions of earnings from pretty much every artist in my community. One thing that Spotify does better than any other DSP is music discovery and recommendation. On Spotify an independent artist with modest buzz around a release can find their track being recommended via Discover Weekly or Release Radar to thousands of new listeners sometimes over night. Spotify also has the most robust user playlist experience out there. Allowing users interoperable playlists I think is a huge boon to us music creators. W/o user playlists and Spotify's music recommendation algorithms I honestly don't know if I could have made a living in music production the past five years b/c all the artists I work with would be broke.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
Ok so from what i can tell, Apple Digital Masters, (previously called MFiT), is basically just a series of guidelines that wants you to 

a) deliver the highest res wave file possible without up sampling
b) avoid clipping (so true peak + reduced ceiling + monitor any clipping through the tools they provide you)
c) preview that after your wav is encoded for Apple Music, you make sure it still sounds good. (the Master for Itunes droplet tool they give you)

If you want that "Apple Digital Master" badge, on the track, you likely have to get it done by someone certified to do an ADM master.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I've spoken with him before, he was really kind and I think cares about the art and people so I think it's important to know that. But I definitely question this logic for the reason you mentioned -- maybe in the wav (I certainly prefer non-true peak limiting vs true peak limiting almost all of the time). But the type of record it is, how important those ISPs are to manage based on possible codec conversion to streaming, all of it is way too complicated a balance to just conclude from one file on an instagram story

He's making it seem like a free lunch -- more ISPs more volume! -- when it's really a balance of factors to consider

And it definitely WON'T sound like a full db louder, if you look at the waveform stats there are only 50k or so samples above 0

In a hot pop record, maybe the ISP and distortion will give a touch of extra percieved volume -- in a piano ballad it could be disastrous (again, easy to check in RX, make an mp3 or OGG)

author: Zach Hughes
content: Folks, I have a question for the group. Would love to get a mastering engineers perspective. I'm curious what is the rationale behind masters clipping output converters and leaving in true peaks that exceed 0dBFS? I get that clipping converters can sound cool / desirable, but why not achieve the clipping you want and then print a final master under zero? Why risk a consumer product crapping out during playback and adding potential distortion and why totally disregard pretty much every DSP's recommendation that true peaks not exceed -1 for the encoding process? I'm noticing that a ton of major label releases are peaking above zero with loudness normalization turned off on Spotify.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
3) Allow artists to retarget their listeners for advertising purposes. Imagine putting a facebook retargeting pixel on your spotify profile page.
4) Allow artists to own their own data. Related to three. Spotify For Artists analytics is a neat distraction. There could be so much more.
5) In the OG spotify days you could direct message other Spotify users which made it way easier to reach out to playlisters and promote your music. Granted this would probably get spammy real fast.
6) Switching from a pro rata payout model to a user centric payout model. Given how spotify calculates the royalty pool currently the greater the total number of streams on the platform the LESS an individual stream is worth. Therefore the value of a stream has been decreasing for years. In 2017 I was making closer to $0.004 / stream and now I am making closer to $0.0026.
7) Eliminate fraudulent streams from the platform. Switching to a user-centric model would eliminate a vast amount of streaming fraud over night. Spotify currently has very little incentive to police streaming fraud. What do they care? They scrape their 30-40% off the top.
8) Democratize editorial playlists inclusion instead of making it a major label circle jerk

I could go on but this is maybe getting excessive

author: Zach Hughes
content: I mean relative in that if you turned a -8LUFS mastered track down 1dB with your fader it would output -9LUFS. And if your master once normalized on Spotify is turned down then the true peak is lowered (if measuring system output from Spotify) the same decibel amount the track is turned down to reach -14 LUFS. The true peak of a track with greater dynamic range that is turned down less or not at all post normalization will be higher. So relative peak levels upon playback, with normalization on, of tracks mastered at varying LUFS values is what I mean.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: This is a bad idea with unpredictable results in the real world. MP3 or any lossy codec works by throwing away information that it deems to be unnecessary becuase of frequency masking. When you upload your WAV (made from MP3) for streaming it will be data compressed again - MP3/AAC/OGG. This will result in very compounded data compression artifacts

author: Rob Domos
content: Well considering apple does SRC in the background without telling you so that you can seemlessly switch between YouTube at 48k and Spotify at 44.1k without anything switching on the hardware layer, shit can sound different there too

author: Rob Domos
content:
I’m not sure it’s quite that simple. A lot of background SRC happens along various stages of information transfer without our knowledge and it’s not clear how they handle mixed sample rates from various applications being accessible to core audio at once. 

Example of SRC we’re generally unaware of: Airpods run at 48k no matter what, and Spotify is at 44.1  no matter what, so any time spotify is listened to through airpods there’s SRC happening. To make it even worse, if the song you are listening to was uploaded at 48, you’re getting two rounds of conversion. Down to 44 and back up to 48.

Software engineers who can’t hear the difference and value user ease of experience are happy to do this willynilly many times over if it’s convenient from a software perspective. 

With core audio, all applications, which run at different sample rates at the same time, all get summed to one channel in a way that I don’t know or understand that math decisions behind (and I’m not aware of anyone who does know the math decisions behind it, I’d love to chat with anyone who does), and it is then fed to us from that channel. How that’s handled feels like a black box to me

author: Joshua Riley
content:
Main takeaways: 

Always get a second opinion 
Let your emotions cool down before you respond to an artist 

Context: 

An artist I work with regularly has a relatively small budget and isn’t the most experienced with the mix/master side. 
Every track I’ve mixed for him, he’s had it mastered for free by an ME. Two songs ago he got onto experimenting with AI mastering which he thankfully moved off of because the tracks sounded horrible. 
This last track we did, he had another ME offer to do a test master on it. I was down and just asked if I could hear it before it goes out. Fast forward, he uploads the track and the first time I hear about it was through socials. So I asked if he went with that ME and how it sounded and got told no, his drummer mate ended up mastering the track. 
So I just got quite frustrated as him and I have quite an open relationship. Mainly because it didn’t sound that great. There was a bunch of true peak overs which thankfully I’m less stressed about after speaking to Jack
So I’m struggling to see if this is ego or just that I don’t trust this person who mastered the track.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
From my understanding it's:

1. Album is given an integrated LUFS score as a whole, and taken down (or turned up) according to the integrated score

2. Album is turned down or up according to the LUFS score of ONLY the loudest song on an album

Dale says what's happening is #2 on Spotify

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Alright I'm back with another question for the hive mind:

Finishing up an EP today we've been slow-dripping for awhile. First song we did had big drums, tons of low, measures louder (-8.4 LUFS). Mastered and approved before the rest of them came this way. Rest of the songs are sparse, open, beautiful. But accordingly meausre much lower (loudest is -11 LUFS). 

So with the new info Dale posted the other day re: how Spotify is normalizing levels, I thought let's just turn down the louder one a little to see how it fits (it's fine), maybe that can buy us a db or whatever for the other songs when they normalize to the loudest song as long as the creative intent is preserved (it is). And that's cool. But actually a better result IMO was to just ease up on the loudness of the first song (at -8.4 LUFS), it makes more sense in the project being a bit more dynamic rather than having the dense one be pulled down.

Question is: will this cause the single version to be replaced by the new album one when going to distro?

I've had masters that we replaced before with a lowered ceiling in projects and all was fine, but the actual master was exactly the same minus the ceiling, so in a single context it would normalize the same. I know to keep exact length to ms, etc etc. 

But the new info Dale posted makes me rethink how to handle this in albums (on Spotify -- on Apple is doesn't seem to be doing that?)

author: Montano Mastering
content:
New to the discord here but just read through the ADM chat and have an interesting follow up.

I am certified to provide ADM. About a year ago I noticed that a label I work with was submitting my non-ADM files to Apple as ADM and still getting certified. I asked the label to use the ADM files in the future as I didnt want to risk my accreditation. They responded that nothing had been flagged by distribution nor by Apple but they would do so moving forward.

Flash forward to this year - I noticed that some ADM files from other engineers had overs, not just clipping but significant overs, check the newest Olivia Rodrigo album. According to the aforementioned document, definitely not to spec hahah.

Flash forward from there to about a month ago, I submitted my standard formats to another label I work with including standard streaming WAV as well as an ADM file. Through chatting with their distribution team it came to light that at the distro end of things they could only upload 1 file (the ADM) and this file would be delivered to each DSP in the specs they can receive, which I found very interesting since the ADM file is occasionally different than the other streaming WAVs.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
For gapless I print a single file with all processing

Then find a zero crossing and split into 2 separate tracks, I don’t do a little fade in or out

Re checking if it worked, iTunes is not a reliable indicator of anything ever, it’s a dead product now

You need to test several things to QC properly, all of these will bite you in the ass at some point

1) Does the end of the first track (from the split file) play cleanly on it’s own

2) Does the second track play cleanly (the start) on its own?

If so great. Now the big caveat 

Streaming services serve up many different types of files - OGG, AAC, MP3, FLAC and ALAC. From memory AAC and MP3 both add small amounts of silence at the start of file when you compress the file, this is done automatically during the data compression (and silence added can even vary depending on codec used and sample rate)

This means that what was a seamless transition between your spliced files will now have a gap, sometimes that creates an audible disturbance, sometimes not

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It means that what is a nice seamless transition locally can go wrong in certain streaming services sometimes, and it’s hard to predict. It can be fine on Spotify mobile but not on desktop because of the different codecs served

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: MP3 and AAC most important

author: Will Pragnell
content: How much are people worrying about mono compatibility in 2025? I know that many small bluetooth speakers, etc. are still summing to mono, so it feels like it matters to me. That said, I'm noticing a lot of recent releases that seem not to care. Latest example is https://tidal.com/browse/track/371179904?u - huge chunks of the strings just dissapear in mono, and looking at a correlation meter while it's playing I can see that it's negative a lot of the time. Would you have let this go out like this? How do you approach it if you get a mix like this? (edit to clarify: not asking about the technical side of how to fix this sort of thing, asking about how you think about this kind of stereo material, how you approach it with clients if you feel it needs changing, etc.)

author: Will Pragnell
content:
Great question. Let me try to answer. I suspect this may be where the learning opportunity lies...

I think what matters to me is that 1) the piece is presented in the best way possible to maximise its impact or essence 2) the piece is listenable and that impact is not lost in a wide range of environments / contexts (i was tempted to say "it translates well" but I think that's a subtly different thing) 3) the client is happy with the result, and feel confident releasing their art, feeling good about it, feeling it's the best version of what it could be.

I think it's point 3 that gives me pause. You can count my paying mastering clients on one hand, so I'm as "beginner level" as it gets, but that said, when i talk to those clients, they share with me that they want a mastering engineer to ensure that their music is going to "sound right on streaming platforms and translate well to lots of systems". There's a lot of FUD about loudness normalisation, LUFS, etc. I don't think it's a huge leap to feel that we should also be thinking about common playback devices such as airpods, and bluetooth speakers. For clients who aren't seasoned mixers or record makers, I wonder how they would feel if they listened to their mastered record on a bluetooth speaker and heard that whole parts had practically vanished. Of course I'm also sensitive to not wanting to introduce doubt in their minds unnecessarily.

author: Ted Whitten Media
content: A little update to an earlier discussion about gapless playback on Spotify. I was able to actually get in touch with someone who confirmed that both their OGG and AAC streams have gapless capability, and, more importantly, they also confirmed that gapless is simply designed to remove the silence added by the encoding process and will not touch anything in the original master. So at least timing wise, listening to an album with gapless playback enabled should exactly match the master.

author: masteredbyjack
content: But once you understand it and study it you can absolutely apply the concept in musical ways if it fits the track, I have for sure gotten things to come on Spotify, etc at least +1db louder with essentially zero downside (I'd argue more connection) when it fits the record

author: masteredbyjack
content: it almost certainly would not be a problem on release -- Spotify and everything will play back with a lower peak value than the digital file and thus break ups solved (usually). I know you so I know you would leave enough headroom for good codec conversion

author: masteredbyjack
content: But if anything of the genre "spotify sounds fine but the master is clipping my phone/car" and it's happening when the volume is turned all the way up, usually it's a digital file peak thing, that the master is playing back near the edge of what these systems can handle

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Do you guys ever play around with slience at the beginning of a track? I usually set things to be pretty tight but with a bit of room to avoid issues with codecs etc. Lately I've been thinking about how it changes the feel of a record when you hit play and it starts immediately vs if there's an extra second of dramatic silence (similar to when there's some noise or ambience before things start). Maybe it's just me so curious to see if this is something others are thinking about

author: masteredbyjack
content: This, and you can study it by using RX, and converting masters down to OGG, mp3, etc and listening

author: masteredbyjack
content: So for instance, a very clean piano track that is sparse im not letting true peaks in, because I’ve studied how that will codec convert (or a DAC can make the true peaks into real peaks when it goes to analog, etc)

author: Ted Whitten Media
content:
When doing revisions, does anyone save a whole new project file with a version number appended to the end? Wondering if that might help me stay more organized. Currently working on an album where the client wanted to go back to V1 for release, and I swear I kept track of every move I'd made to get to v2, but for some reason I just couldn't get it to sound exactly like V1 again. It's no problem on their end because they just used the file I'd rendered and uploaded to Samply. But now I have a clip in my montage that doesn't match the released version, which I don't like. I ended up dropping the master on a reference track instead.

I think this issue was partially caused because I tend to send an initial rough master too early in the process and they get demo-itis. For some reason I've always wanted to send clients an initial rough master after I've done the quick "from the gut" broad strokes, but before I've totally nailed down the nitty gritty stuff, to see if they like the direction I'm headed. And all too often they end up liking the first version.

Or maybe I'm just overthinking v2 and making it worse on a regular basis? I dunno... 😂

author: Jasper Boogaard
content:
I think the chance for playlisting here would be a lot higher if there’s a new team/label behind it pushing it to streaming services’ editorial teams. In my experience the label’s PR team is still very important in playlisting and if the remaster gets a new push from a new label that might help a lot.  

if they do a smart repackaging as a deluxe remastered album, maybe add a live version or bonus track, this might help too. They will definitely get another push in the Spotify Release Radar which is a good source of new streams.

author: Berlin
content:
Hey there. The only way it would work is if it's an all new release, with new ISRC and UPC and everything.. but even then Spotify may see that it's a previously released track for this artist and not allow it for Playlist submissions. If you share the same metadata, track lengths, etc etc.. if it all looks the same, it will likely not be available to that artist for play listing at all.

So PR, MGMT, Label relationships with Apple, Spotify, etc would be the best fail proof approach I think there. Of if they get a distro deal like with Tone Tree or Symphonic who can help bring new life to the release.

Just leaning on the algos and stuff won't do it in this case, I really thing a human working the release relationally is what it would take.
